descendants.content:
@iamsambarton what also really annoys me about a lot of these things is the extreme greenwashing.

And paper straws are some of the worst offenders.

Sure they aren't made out of plastic anymore.
Only that paper requires even more energy than plastic during manufacturing.

And to be at least somewhat fluid resistant the paper is usually drenched in glue which, as recent research showed, often contains "forever chemicals" which accumulate in our body and do who knows what kinda long-term damage.

descendants.content:
@iamsambarton
One report about that topic:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0045653521007074

Those straws are in many cases even worse for the environment than the old plastic ones, both in their manufacturing and from the waste they create.

The proper alternative are either no straws at all or reusable metal or glass ones.

descendants.content:
@xChaos Yes, some of the demand is real.
But even if the demand goes away, who do you think will make the "alternative" product?

There's almost no way of truly "escaping" those corporations without moving into a forest and living off the land by yourself.

The paper straws are the best example.
They were created by chemical corporations to circumvent the plastic straw ban.

And they still contain bad chemicals (in some cases even more than plastic straws) that are bad for the environment.

descendants.content:
@elmo Actually, I am from the culture, which doesn't use straws at all (maybe children use them). Most of beverages I drink is water (mostly tap water) , tea, coffee or beer (alcohol-free or classical, preferably local breweries, draft). None of these potions is consumed by straw, so I am really too oldschool to understand this dispute 🙂

But corporations are just money-powered machines. From computation point of view, there are kind of "deterministic finite automatons"... there are states, predefined, and money and products move between these states, because there is demand and people are willing to spend money for something, and sometimes the flavor of that something changes, and that's it.

People on corporations just do their work and nobody tasked them to propose solution and corporations were not even created to be able to do it. They are good at optimizing certain parameters, but the problem who should task them them with optimizing parameters like carbon footprint, which is incredibly complex, because it usually go down the supply chain and even if the try, with globalization, you just end manufacturing everything using coal energy in China....

But still, it is the consumers who *should* have the imagination and change the demand. But this just won't happen. But because you don't want to blame consumers (because it inevitably includes ourselves) you just somehow blame corporations, but they are not persons, they are machines. They just include lot of people following orders and doing their jobs. And they don't want to blame themselves, excactly like we don't like to blame themselves. And everybody thinks, that maybe AI will magically invent some solution, but AI also lacks imagination. We should have it, actually.

Celebrities make money by their images being shared and this thread started by sharing one such image. And celebrities without money wouldn't have money to do stupid things. Problem solved.

descendants.content:
@xChaos Your viewpoint on how corporations work is way too optimistic and completely out of touch with the actual reality.

Here's just an example to show you how wrong you are:

Monsanto.
Arguably one of the worst offenders of the biochemical industry, created a crop that can not be naturally re-grown on it's own.
Makes no sense right?

Well not for the farmers at least.
It very much does so for Monsanto.

Because now farmers have to constantly buy new crops from them instead of regrowing them

descendants.content:
@elmo see above, I am no fan of Monsanto, maybe I was talking about more simple corporations. But in a way, Monsanto is also example of what I am talking about, because they are just focused on simple tricks which increase their profit and don't care about anything else. So in a way, their employees just do the stuff their were told to, their lobbyist do the stuff their were told to... it is still just pretty dumb machine.

But oil mining business is really even much more simple, because it doesn't require regulations to force people burn fuel in their cars. Quite opposite: there are many regulations aimed at reducing fuel consumption, fuel taxes, emission limits and regulations... but people still continue buying.

So there are definitely corporations who don't need any complex lobbying, and are powered just by the force of dumb everyday mass consumption.

I tend to think about rich not as about organizers of all this, but rather like surfers, who surf the tsunami-size waves and enjoy it. This is probably cynical. But they are not reasons why the waves are there.

So basically, I don't think that there is any level of hierarchical management, which can easily change the way the world and economy runs. Not the oligarch, not the management. Research can invent stuff, but has no power to put it in mass production. Government pretends it has more resources and power, than it actually has.

So you can of course continue blaming THEM, but there are no THEM. There are only us, in a fractal-structured society, and there is not a single "firm place to stand", from which anyone can "move the Earth".

But it is nice, that we now have Fediverse, where we can at least discuss this...

descendants.content:

The problem of intensive industrialized farming is, that together with economies of scale, it just allows for agricultural production with less workforce.

Anyway, I am no fan of Monsanto and different agricultural philosophy was on of show stoppers of free trade agreement between USA and EU.

descendants.content:
@intransitivelie @elmo well, of course... luxuries are completely different category of consumption. People are not buying them, people are buying social status, which si derived solely from scarcity - not from any actual utility. The social status can be displayed publicly or privately.

Being able to do transatlantic flights just for fun is also way to display social status. Its obvious, that there is demand for higher social status, social status can be traded, and so on.

But it is clear, that this is not enforced by people who sell luxuries - they just smartly surf the wave. First of all, there are simple people willing to acquire some elevated social status and to display it publicly, and perhaps to exchange it for something. So you go deep in the rabbit hole of not-so-smart people willing to risk and place some bets and some of them win and they than want to display that they won and convert their luck into chance to visibly display their social status.

Compared to the consumer stupidity, the people who satisfy these completely pointless demands are relatively hard working...

Marketing and advertising is yet another story. Some of the demand is completely artificial, that's right. But the entire narrative, that consumers are complete victims, who were somehow forced to consume, is almost as far from reality, as the opposite extreme of climate denial...

fields.name: Web

descendants.content:
@xChaos @elmo
Deodorant isn't a luxury. As for diamond producers merely surfing a wave, you're just wrong. The demand for diamonds was entirely constructed by De Beers, who had a lot of diamonds they couldn't sell to the average person. The diamond engagement ring? A demand which was created by De Beers. Diamonds are kept artificially scarce by De Beers to drive up prices and make people think diamonds are more luxurious than they actually are.

I'm not absolving consumers of their responsibilities, I'm just saying that consumer demand is largely manufactured by the producers. We as consumers need to consume less, but the things we consume are decided by Madison Ave. It's not just luxury goods. And the vast majority of people don't know any better because it's as baked into our system as white supremacy is. You can't fix it within the system.

That's the point people are making when they say that most pollution is done by corporations. You can't fix that by individual choices. You have to change the system, which requires collective action. So yes, sure, it's great to, as an individual, change one's consumption patterns, but it won't save us.

Look at planned obsolescence. You can't fight that by changing your patterns of consumption. If you need electronic devices, appliances, whatever, they're all designed to fail more quickly and be impossible to repair. You can't boycott those devices because there are no alternatives. That's the system. The individual has no ability to affect change through their individual choices except as part of a group. So sure, criticize the consumer, but don't fool yourself into thinking that individual action can help. Paper straws, personal carbon footprints, recycling, etc. distract from the fact that the individual is being blamed for systemic faults.

No one is saying that consumers are victims. But to say that corporations are machines that aren't directed? Come now, that dog won't hunt.

descendants.content:
@elmo @nutmeg @iamsambarton

I don't get it.
Why should it be a coup of BP.
Think it's just correct what BP is telling you.
Consuming means supporting their lobbyism and subsidies.

If you don't consume oil by driving cars or plastic (...), of course in a big mass, than BP gets less money and less power to influence media and politics by lobbyism.
Following they don't get so much subsidies.
Oil gets more expensive and it makes more sence for many people to drive with bike, bus or train.

Think this often is being forgotten in the criticism of the criticism of consumption.

Yes we have to critisize politics supporting capitalism and rich people at first, but we should also be aware, that we're not completely without influence by our own consume.

For example if people don't follow their channels or making shitstorm on Kim Kardeshian, perhaps other people think twice if they acting shit like that.

Think everybody should do responsible things.
It's not always the others.
It's the consumption AND the politics AND the corporates.
